Graphical abstract Graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) contains abundant nitrogen-containing groups and have demonstrated potential catalysis in several CO2-activating reactions. However, the catalytic activity obtained with the bulk and pristine g-C3N4 is quite low. In this work, g-C3N4 was prepared using dicyandiamide as a precursor, thermally exfoliated, and then treated by HCl solution. The synthesized eg-C3N4−OH were analyzed by various characterization techniques including XRD, N2 adsorption, SEM, FT-IR, UV–vis, XPS, and Raman spectroscopy. The characterization results confirmed that the treatment of HCl induced the generation of hydroxyl groups on the surface of eg-C3N4, depending on the treatment conditions. As metal-free catalysts, the eg-C3N4 materials exhibit high catalytic activities in the cycloaddition reactions of CO2. The effects of HCl treatment on the chemical properties of eg-C3N4 materials and the corresponding catalytic performance have been investigated. Furthermore, the catalytic performance of eg-C3N4−OH was compared with other previously reported g-C3N4-based materials. Keywords Graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) Metal-free catalysis CO2 Cycloaddition Cyclic carbonate 1 Introduction As the most long-lived greenhouse gas originated from anthropogenic emission and fossil-fuel combustion, carbon dioxide (CO2) has been widely considered partially responsible for global warming and its associated climate change [1–3]. In addition to capture and storage technologies, the transformation of CO2 (also called as chemical fixation) into high-value-added compounds could not only utilize CO2 as a C1 feedstock but also offer a sustainable strategy to complement contemporary fossil-based chemical industry [4–6]. Among numerous transformations of CO2, the cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxide (e.g. propylene oxide and styrene oxide) has received great attention in the past decades [1,7]. The products, i.e. five-membered cyclic carbonates, are very important chemicals that are extensively used as fuel additives, polar aprotic solvents, electrolytes in lithium batteries, and the building block for the manufacture of polycarbonates [8,9]. Due to its low reactivity and thermodynamical stability, the activation and chemical transformation of CO2 usually demand harsh reaction conditions (including higher temperatures and pressures) and involvement of catalysts [10,11]. In the cases of cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxides, a wide range of catalysts have been developed. To date, the most efficient catalysts have been confined as several organic materials including metal-organic complexes [4,12–14], quaternary ammonium/phosphonium salts [2,7,8], and ionic liquid [15–19]. Despite their excellent catalytic activities and mild operation conditions, the major practical drawback in the use of these catalysts lies in their intrinsically homogeneous nature, which impedes its large-scale application because of the difficulties in catalyst‒product separation as well as production purification [1,8,11,20]. Although the immobilization of ionic liquids and other abovementioned homogeneous materials onto supports (including mesoporous silica and polymer) could smoothly circumvent the issue of catalyst recovery [21,22], the immobilization procedure is indeed not economic and complicated [8,23]. On the other hand, many heterogeneous catalysts suffer from low catalytic activities and stringent operating conditions. More importantly, most heterogeneous catalysts contain metallic components (especially Zn2+ [24–27]), inevitably bringing about potential metallic contamination into the final cyclic carbonates [9,28]. In this sense, it is still a great challenge to develop a metal-free heterogeneous that can afford high activity in the cycloaddition of CO2. Owing to the combination of multiple special physicochemical properties, graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) has attracted wide attention in various research fields including catalysis [29–33], gas storage [34], electrochemistry [35], etc. In particular, the g-C3N4 material contains abundant nitrogen-containing chemical functionalities in the forms of amino groups, which dictates it to be a typical solid base. Up to now, several research groups including ours have reported that the g-C3N4 materials (especially those owing high surface areas and/or porosity) could catalyze Knoevenagel condensation [36,37], transesterification [38,39], and CO2-activating reactions [11,27,40,41]. However, the catalytic activity obtained in the pristine or bulk g-C3N4 for the cycloaddition of CO2 is very poor owing to its very low surface area [11,27,41,42]. Meanwhile, because of the scarcity of metal cation or halogen species, the activation of epoxide by g-C3N4 is hard to proceed. In this sense, the modification of g-C3N4 is very necessary for its up-gradation in catalyzing the reaction. In this contribution, we developed a convenient approach for the preparation of hydroxyl-functionalized eg-C3N4 materials by thermal exfoliation and HCl (a.q.) treatment. The synthesized eg-C3N4−OH showed catalytic activity in the cycloaddition of CO2 with propylene epoxide (PO). The effect of HCl treatment on the surface of eg-C3N4 materials and final catalytic activity are deliberated studied. Additionally, the catalytic performance of the eg-C3N4−OH in the cycloaddition reaction has been compared with other reported g-C3N4-based catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The g-C3N4 material was synthesized using thermal condensation using dicyandiamide (DCDA) as a precursor. Briefly, 5 g of DCDA was added into a ceramic crucible with a cover, and heated from room temperature to 550 °C (ramping rate: 3 °C min−1) in a muffle furnace. After heating at 550 °C for 4 h, the solid was collected and then ground. The obtained yellowish powder was g-C3N4, and the mass was ca. 2.0 g. Subsequently, 1 g of the g-C3N4 powder was transferred into a crucible with a cover and further treated under 550 °C for another 3 h. The resultant powder was labeled as eg-C3N4, where e stood for thermal exfoliation. 0.6 g of eg-C3N4 or g-C3N4 was added into a round-bottomed flask containing 20 mL of HCl, and then refluxed at 90 °C for 4 h under vigorous stirring. Afterward, the mixture was centrifuged and the solid was rinsed by deionized water for three times, and then dried overnight at 80 °C. Finally, the yellow powder was obtained and designated as eg-C3N4−OH-x and g-C3N4−OH, where x indicated the molar concentration (1–3 M) of HCl (a.q.). Unless specified, x was 2 M. 2.2 Sample characterization The specific surface areas (S BET) of the materials were measured using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 analyzer. Prior to the analysis, the samples were degassed (1.33 × 10−2 Pa) at 150 °C for at least 4 h. The S BET values were calculated according to the Brunauer–Emmet–Teller (BET) method using adsorption data at the relative pressure (p/p 0) in the range of 0.05–0.30. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded with a Rigaku D/max 2500 PC X-ray diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromator (40 kV, 40 mA) using Ni-filtered Cu-Kα radiation (λ =1.5418 Å). Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra of the samples were collected in transmission mode on a Bruker Tensor 27 spectrometer with a resolution of 4 cm−1, using 32 scans per spectrum in the region of 400–4000 cm−1. The mass ratio of every sample to KBr was constant at 1:200. X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS) were recorded on a Thermo ESCALAB 250XI spectrometer using an Al anode as an X-ray source with a working voltage of 12.5 kV. The carbonaceous C 1s line (284.6 eV) was used as the reference to calibrate the binding energies (B.E.). UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra (DRS) were tested by a Shimadzu UV-3600 spectrophotometer. BaSO4 was used as a standard reference. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was analyzed on a Supra 55 (Zeiss) microscope operating at 30 kV. Raman spectra were recorded at room temperature on a Raman spectrometer (Renishaw InVia) using Ar+ laser (785 nm) as an excitation source. 2.3 Catalytic evaluation Cycloaddition reactions of CO2 with PO to propylene carbonate (PC) were conducted in a stainless steel autoclave (25 mL, Anhui Kemi Machinery Co. Ltd). 8 mL of PO (115 mmol), 2 mL of N, N-dimethyl formamide (DMF), and 0.2 g of catalyst were added into the reactor, which was then pressurized with CO2 to 2.0 MPa. The reaction was carried out at 140 °C under vigorous stirring for 6 h. After completion of the reaction, the liquid-phase mixture was separated by centrifugation, and then analyzed by gas chromatogram (GC). The liquid mixture contained PO, PC, and 1,2-propylene glycol (PG) as the byproduct derived from hydrolysis of PO with trace H2O. The carbon balance was nearly 100 %. PO conversion and selectivity to PC were calculated based on an area-normalization method and the corresponding calculation equations are as follows: C o n v . = A PC × f PC + A PG × f PG A PO + A PC × f PC + A PG × f PG , S e l . = A PC × f PC A PC × f PC + A PG × f PG where A and f are the peak areas of GC and response factor for each product, respectively. The quasi-TOF (mass of synthesized cyclic carbonate per gram catalyst per hour) for each catalyst was calculated as follows: TOF = m CC W catal . × t = n epoxide × Y i e l d % × M CC W catal . × t where n epoxide, M CC, t, and W catal. were the molar amount (mol) of epoxide, formula weight (g mol−1) of cyclic carbonate (CC), reaction time (h), and the mass of overall catalyst (g), respectively. 3 Results & discussion 3.1 Structure characterization Fig. 1 describes the XRD patterns of g-C3N4 and eg-C3N4 materials. All the patterns exhibit intensive diffraction peaks in ca. 27°, which are assigned to the graphitic interlayer stacking structures [43,44], i.e. (002) reflection. In addition, a weak peak could be observed at ca. 13° for each XRD pattern [45,46]. The diffraction corresponds to the intralayer structural packing motif, i.e. (100) reflection. Judging from the magnified regions, it is found that compared with the XRD patterns of g-C3N4 and g-C3N4−OH, the (002) peaks of eg-C3N4 and eg-C3N4−OH shift towards higher 2θ degrees. The reduction of the interlayer distance of g-C3N4 materials is probably caused by the thermal squeezing occurring in the thermal-decomposition-based exfoliation (i.e. the second thermal treatment of g-C3N4). A similar phenomenon has also been found in the exfoliated [47,48] and thermally treated g-C3N4 materials [49,50]. Overall, neither the thermal exfoliation nor HCl treatment procedure has affected the primary graphitic structure of g-C3N4 material. The surface areas of g-C3N4 and various eg-C3N4 materials are summarized in Table 1 . The pristine g-C3N4 has a very low specific surface area (9 m2 g−1) whereas the eg-C3N4 owns a high surface area up to 55 m2 g−1, Obviously, after the exfoliation, the surface area of g-C3N4 has been remarkably enhanced. However, the surface areas of g-C3N4 and eg-C3N4 have not suffered apparent change after the HCl treatment. The micro-morphology of the materials are characterized by SEM. The SEM images (Fig. 2 ) of the pristine g-C3N4 reveal irregular large aggregated particles. In comparison, the images of eg-C3N4 display a large number of small strips. It is noted that the exfoliation procedure of g-C3N4 is based on the thermal decomposition of nitrogen-containing fragments of g-C3N4 [48]. The decomposition of such species under high temperature could partially destroy the graphitic intralayer sheets of g-C3N4, which is reflected by the weakened intensity of (100) reflection from g-C3N4 to eg-C3N4 (Fig. 1). Moreover, the original large particles of eg-C3N4 would also transform into small particles upon exfoliation. This could also explain the enhanced surface area from g-C3N4 to eg-C3N4. Fig. 3 A presents the UV–vis diffuse reflectance spectra of g-C3N4 and eg-C3N4 materials. All the materials own typical semiconductor absorption. The pronounced absorption in the UV region is detected for each spectrum of the materials, which is ascribed to the bandgap between HOMO and LUMO in the polymeric triazine units of g-C3N4 [29,51]. The corresponding Tauc plots ((αhν)1/2 versus hν) and the corresponding bandgap energies of various samples are given in Fig. 3B and Table S1, respectively. The results evidence apparent blue shift of absorption edges (of g-C3N4 and g-C3N4−OH with respect to eg-C3N4 and eg-C3N4−OH. The modification of the optical property of g-C3N4 upon exfoliation is presumably due to the strong quantum confinement in the exfoliated g-C3N4 samples, which has also been previously reported in the cases of g-C3N4 nanosheets [48,50,52]. The chemical functionalities of the materials were analyzed by FT-IR spectroscopy. All the spectra (Fig. 4 ) exhibit three transmission regions. The multiple bands ranging from 1230 to 1650 cm−1 are attributed to the stretching modes in aromatic CN heterocycles [45]. The sharp bands located at 806 cm−1 are indexed as the widespread stretching vibration (also called breathing mode) of triazine units [45], evidence of the π-conjugated structure of g-C3N4. The broad bands in the range of 3050–3300 cm−1 are associated with the stretching vibrations of NH bonds and HO bonds of adsorbed water [53]. Compared with that of the pristine g-C3N4, the transmission bands gained in the exfoliated and treated g-C3N4 materials become more resolved in this region, indicating that these materials own more exposed amino and hydroxyl groups. XPS was further employed to analyze the chemical composition of the materials. The spectrum of eg-C3N4 (Fig. S1) displays three well-resolved signals located at 530, 399, and 289 eV, which are indexed as oxygen, nitrogen, and carbon elements, respectively. The HCl-treated eg-C3N4−OH reveals a similar spectrum with the eg-C3N4. Calculated based on the elemental peaks, the molar ratios of the three elements are listed in Table 2 . It can be seen that after HCl treatment, the oxygen proportions of eg-C3N4 materials are remarkably increased. In order to further elucidate the detailed chemical bonding states of the materials, high-resolution spectra of the materials were acquired. As presented in Fig. 5 , two independent peaks are observed in the C 1s spectrum of g-C3N4. The major signal with the low binding energy (288.1 eV) is identified as sp2-hybridized carbon bonding with two nitrogen atoms in triazine rings (NC = N) [44,54], while the minor peak centered at 284.7 eV corresponds to the sp2-bonded carbon atoms (CC) [11,54–56]. In the cases of eg-C3N4−OH materials, the above two peaks can be found in their C 1s spectra. However, a minute peak is found at 286.4 eV in each spectrum of eg-C3N4−OH. The weak signal is associated with carbon atoms connected with hydroxyl groups (C–OH) [57,58]. Taking into account the abovementioned HO bonds revealed by FT-IR spectra above, it can be inferred that, the HCl treatment induces the generation of hydroxyl groups on the surface of eg-C3N4 materials. Fig. 6 depicts the high-resolution O 1s spectra of the materials. The spectrum of the bare eg-C3N4 shows one peak centered at 532.4 ± 0.2 eV, corresponding to (HOH) functionalities derived from the adsorbed water on the surface of the sample [53,59,60]. In comparison, the peaks acquired in the cases of eg-C3N4−OH samples can be separated into two signals. The second peaks with the binding energy of 531.6 eV are ascribed to hydroxyl groups (C–O‒H) [46,61], which are consistent with the above FT-IR analytic results. According to the fine O 1s spectra, it can be found that eg-C3N4−OH-2 owns the highest proportion of hydroxyl groups among the three eg-C3N4−OH samples. The N 1s spectra of eg-C3N4 and eg-C3N4−OH-2 materials are described in Fig. 7 . The spectra are deconvoluted into three peaks. The dominance of the spectra with the lowest binding energy (398.7 eV) is indexed as the sp2-hybridized nitrogen atoms (Na) in the CN = C groups in the tri-s-triazine rings [44]. The peaks located at 399.8 eV and 401.1 eV correspond to the bridging nitrogen atoms (Nb) in the forms of CNHC and C–N(–C)–C) functionalities and terminal amino groups (–NH2, Nc) located at the edges of graphitic sheets of g-C3N4, respectively [28,62]. The molar percentages of Nb and Nc species in eg-C3N4 are 17.5 % and 10.7 %. By comparison, the values obtained in eg-C3N4−OH are 13.8 % and 13.2 %, respectively. Regarding the variation, it is reasonably inferred that, for the eg-C3N4 sample, the HCl treatment induces partial transformation of the bridging nitrogen into terminal nitrogen species. Besides FT-IR and XPS, Raman spectroscopy was also applied to probe the structure of eg-C3N4 materials. As depicted in Fig. 8 , the spectrum of eg-C3N4 reveals peaks at 1118, 1156, 1217, and 1235 cm−1, characteristic Raman bands of g-C3N4 materials [61]. All the bands are observed on the spectra of HCl-treated samples, suggesting that the graphitic structure of eg-C3N4 has remained after HCl treatment. Additionally, a weak but apparent band emerges at 1139 cm−1 in the cases of eg-C3N4−OH-1 and eg-C3N4−OH-2, which is associated with the C–O bonds, further confirming the existence of hydroxyl groups on the eg-C3N4 after HCl treatment. Based on the analytic results of several spectroscopy techniques, a possible mechanism of HCl treatment on g-C3N4 is speculated. As illustrated in Scheme 1 , g-C3N4 was built up with tri-s-triazine tectonic units bridged by tertiary nitrogen atoms. After the HCl treatment, partial bridging nitrogen functionalities of g-C3N4 were hydrolyzed, resulting in the breakage of adjacent tri-s-triazine units. Thereby, hydroxyl and uncondensed amino groups are created. Notwithstanding, the use of excessively high concentration of HCl (a.q.) would damage the terminal amino groups, and probably weaken the overall basicity of g-C3N4. 3.2 Catalyst evaluation The catalytic performances of various materials were evaluated in the cycloaddition reactions of CO2 and PO to PC (Table 3 ). In the presence of 200 mg g-C3N4, PO is hard to be converted (entry 1). Also, without any catalyst, the PO conversion is very low (entry 2). Using the HCl-treated sample, i.e. g-C3N4−OH-2 instead, the catalytic conversion is increased to 22 % (entry 3). As for the product distributions, the main product is PC and the other is PG that probably comes from the partial hydrolysis of PO with the residual water in the reactor [15,27,46]. Compared with the bare g-C3N4, the eg-C3N4 exhibits higher catalytic conversion (19 %, entry 4), implying that higher surface area could expose much more catalytic sites in the reaction. After the HCl treatment, the catalytic activities obtained in the eg-C3N4 materials are remarkably enhanced (entries 5–7). Among such eg-C3N4−OH catalysts, eg-C3N4−OH-2 exhibits the highest catalytic activity under identical reaction conditions. In the case of eg-C3N4−OH-3, as explained above, HCl (a.q.) with high concentration could damage the terminal amino groups and probably weaken the overall basicity of g-C3N4. As a result, as a solid base, the capability in activating acidic CO2 molecules of eg-C3N4−OH-3 becomes lower than eg-C3N4−OH-2. Additionally, the catalytic performance in the absence of DMF was also evaluated under the same reaction conditions, and the corresponding PO conversion is 36 %, along with selectivity to PC of 96 % (entry 8). Apparently, DMF is capable of promoting the catalytic process, owing to its basic property that facilitates the adsorption and activation of CO2 for the cycloaddition reactions [26,30,63]. In addition to varying the concentration of HCl (a.q.), we have also adjusted the treatment temperature of HCl (a.q.) and prepared a series of eg-C3N4−OH-2 materials. As described in Fig. 9 , the treatment temperature also plays an important role in determining the final catalytic activity of eg-C3N4−OH-2 materials. As the temperature is elevated from room temperature to 90 °C, the catalytic conversion of PO is progressively increased. Nevertheless, adopting higher treatment temperatures, the eg-C3N4−OH-2 catalyst shows a drop in catalytic activity. According to the speculation illustrated in Scheme 1, more bridging nitrogen species convert into amino and hydroxyl groups in eg-C3N4−OH after the HCl treatment. Hence, the catalytic conversion is increased with the increase of the treatment temperature of eg-C3N4. However, the acidic HCl solution could also neutralize the basic amino groups of eg-C3N4, which are actually very important in activating CO2 molecules. Undoubtedly, the effect inevitably impedes the overall catalytic activity of eg-C3N4−OH in the cycloaddition reactions. It is widely recognized that, in the heterogeneous catalytic cycloaddition of CO2 with epoxide, CO2 molecules are commonly adsorbed and activated by basic sites on the surface of the solid catalyst. As noted above, g-C3N4-based materials have intrinsic abundant basic sites in the forms of uncondensed amino groups and bridging nitrogen atoms [30,64]. The feature enables them (especially the materials owning high surface areas) as solid bases in CO2-involving reactions [27,28,30,46]. In the case of epoxide, the activating process via ring-opening of epoxide is commonly promoted by transitional metal cations and/or halide anions [24–26,65]. Besides, the metal-free groups including hydroxyl and amino groups have also been reported to be able to activate epoxide molecules [28,42,46,53]. Since the above analytic results indicate that the hydroxyl groups are generated on the surface of eg-C3N4 after the HCl treatment, the surface acidic property of eg-C3N4 materials was tested by a simple method in this work. In brief, the pre-dried samples are added into water. After stirring under a constant temperature, the pH values of the mixture were recorded. Table 4 summarizes the resultant pH values of various eg-C3N4 powder. The pH value of the pristine eg-C3N4 is 7.57. As expected, eg-C3N4−OH materials show lower pH values, confirming that the materials possess a higher strength of acidity than the eg-C3N4. Undoubtedly, the variation from eg-C3N4 to eg-C3N4−OH reflects the introduction of hydroxyl groups after HCl treatment. Combining the above catalytic performance (Table 3) and acidic property (Table 4) of the catalysts, it is reasonable to infer that the superior activity of eg-C3N4−OH to eg-C3N4 in the cycloaddition reaction is mainly attributed to the surface hydroxyl groups. With this in mind, we perform some tests to further verify this speculation. As indicated in Table 5 , after eg-C3N4−OH-2 was subsequently treated in ammonia solution, the catalytic activity of the gained solid (eg-C3N4-PA) is very low. Likewise, the post-treatment of eg-C3N4−OH-2 in high temperature results in a drastic decline of the catalytic activity (eg-C3N4-PB). The two post-treatments are believed to destroy the hydroxyl groups and/or partial active nitrogen-containing basic sites of eg-C3N4, thus deteriorating the catalysis in activating PO and/or CO2 molecules. By contrary, if the eg-C3N4-PB sample was further immersed into HCl (a.q.) for another 2 h, a moderate catalytic conversion is retrieved in the resultant eg-C3N4-PC sample. These tests further prove that the hydroxyl groups on the eg-C3N4 derived from HCl treatment are exactly the catalytic active sites in cycloaddition of CO2. Since eg-C3N4−OH owns superior catalytic activity to other materials, the influence of reaction conditions on catalytic performance has been further investigated using eg-C3N4−OH as a catalyst. The PO conversion is only 15 % as the reaction temperature is 110 °C (Fig. 10 A). As the temperature is raised, the conversion is increased progressively. A noticeably high PO conversion is obtained at 150 °C. Nonetheless, the reaction condition is highly demanded and meanwhile, the selectivity to PC is decreased due to partial polymerization of PC. The catalytic reaction is also found to be sensitive to the pressure of CO2. In the low range of pressure, the PO conversion is gradually enhanced as the pressure is elevated (Fig. 10B). However, the higher pressure of CO2 above 2.5 MPa brings about a decrease in PO conversion. One possible reason is that under such a condition, CO2 and PO transform into a strong complex [7]. The catalytic results obtained in different reaction time and catalyst feeding amounts are given in Fig. 11 . Upon prolonging the reaction, the PO conversion is increased continuously. After the reaction proceeds for 12 h, the PO conversion is nearly 80 %. Moreover, the selectivity to PC throughout the whole reaction period is over 95 %. Similarly, using more catalyst in the cycloaddition reaction leads to a smooth improvement of the conversion. However, the yield of PC achieved by per unit mass of the catalyst is in fact decreased. Recyclability and reproducibility are also of importance in elevating a heterogeneous catalyst. Given this issue, after it first catalytic run, the eg-C3N4−OH catalyst was separated by centrifugation, rinsed by menthol for two times, and then used for the next test. As described in Fig. 12 , in the second run, the catalytic conversion underwent a slight decline, which may be due to the loss of small particles of the catalyst during the recycling procedure. Nonetheless, within all the five consecutive catalytic runs, the catalytic conversions are kept over 56 % and meanwhile, the selectivities to PC are all above 95 %. As mentioned above, it is widely reported that acidic CO2 molecules can be adsorbed by the bridging nitrogen atoms and amino groups of g-C3N4 [28,30,41,46]. In this work, the treatment of HCl induces the generation of hydroxyl groups on the surface of eg-C3N4, and the catalytic activities of eg-C3N4 have been enhanced after the HCl treatment. According to the finding and the previously reported papers [66,67], we surmise that the basic nitrogen species and hydroxyl groups of eg-C3N4−OH are essentially active sites in the cycloaddition of CO2 with PO. The proposed catalytic mechanism are illustrated in Scheme 2 . Initially, acidic CO2 molecules are adsorbed and activated by basic nitrogen species of eg-C3N4−OH, thus transforming into carbamates [68]. The PO molecules are also adsorbed by the hydroxyl groups of eg-C3N4−OH by the formation of hydrogen bonds between hydroxyl groups and the oxygen atoms of PO [46,66]. Subsequently, the activated CO2 functionalities attack the less hindered carbon atoms of PO molecules, resulting in the ring-opening thereof. Afterward, intramolecular ring-closure occurs and the target molecules (i.e. PC) are produced. Table 6 summaries the reactions conditions and catalytic results obtained by various g-C3N4-based materials in cycloaddition of epoxides, To the best of our knowledge, it covers almost all the cases recently reported in the literature. It should be stressed that the experimental conditions adopted in each case deviate from each other. Considering this point, quasi-TOF values based on the mass of obtained cyclic carbonate per gram of catalyst per hour are calculated for a rough comparison. Among these g-C3N4-based materials, the highest catalytic activities are achieved in g-C3N4-S and S-CN(UTU)-60; however the substrates are epichlorohydrin, which is actually easy to be activated and converted than PO and styrene oxide. Furthermore, The g-C3N4/SBA-15 and butBr/mp-C3N4 also demonstrate excellent catalytic activities. It is noted that the two catalysts were mesoporous materials using either SBA-15 as catalytic support or silica nanoparticles as sacrificial templates. Undoubtedly, such catalyst preparation is complicated and high-costing. In this sense, compared with other g-C3N4-based catalysts, the present eg-C3N4−OH offers a superior catalytic activity in relatively mild reaction conditions. 4 Conclusion In summary, hydroxyl-functionalized eg-C3N4 materials have been prepared through a simple HCl treatment. The thermal exfoliation procedure enhanced the surface area of g-C3N4 while the HCl treatment facilitated the creation of hydroxyl groups of g-C3N4, which is verified by FT-IR, XPS, and Raman spectra. As a metal-free heterogeneous catalyst, the eg-C3N4−OH showed good catalytic activity and high selectivity (>95 %) in the cycloaddition of CO2 with PO. The hydroxyl groups of eg-C3N4−OH play a crucial role in catalyzing the reaction. Under the reaction temperature of 140 °C and the reaction time of 6 h, the catalytic PC yield was up to 60 %. Prolonging the reaction or adding more catalyst, the PC yield could reach ca. 80 %. In addition, the catalyst was able to be recycled and reused for at least five times without significant loss of catalytic activity. More importantly, under similar reaction conditions, the eg-C3N4−OH revealed higher catalytic activity than other reported g-C3N4-based materials. Combining its steady and good catalytic activity, it is anticipated that the hydroxyl-functionalized eg-C3N4 material could serve as a promising metal-free heterogeneous catalyst for the green synthesis of cyclic carbonates. coredata.dc:description: Graphitic carbon nitride (g-C3N4) contains abundant nitrogen-containing groups and have demonstrated potential catalysis in several CO2-activating reactions. However, the catalytic activity obtained with the bulk and pristine g-C3N4 is quite low. In this work, g-C3N4 was prepared using dicyandiamide as a precursor, thermally exfoliated, and then treated by HCl solution. The synthesized eg-C3N4−OH were analyzed by various characterization techniques including XRD, N2 adsorption, SEM, FT-IR, UV–vis, XPS, and Raman spectroscopy. The characterization results confirmed that the treatment of HCl induced the generation of hydroxyl groups on the surface of eg-C3N4, depending on the treatment conditions. As metal-free catalysts, the eg-C3N4 materials exhibit high catalytic activities in the cycloaddition reactions of CO2. The effects of HCl treatment on the chemical properties of eg-C3N4 materials and the corresponding catalytic performance have been investigated. Furthermore, the catalytic performance of eg-C3N4−OH was compared with other previously reported g-C3N4-based materials.
